page.title:
The United States and Europe: Engines For World Growth
The United States and Europe:

page.title:
ICT Investment Drives Productivity
ICT Investment Drives Productivity
page.enlisting:
▪ U.S. productivity grew 4.7% in Q3-2005 and has grown 3.1% over the past four quarters. From December 2000 to December 2004, productivity grew at its fastest 4-year rate in over 50 years. ◼ From 1Q03-1Q05, major segments of IT investment spending grew ◼ • During the period 1995-2003, US average labor productivity (ALP) increased at ▪ U.S. productivity grew 4.7% in Q3-2005 and has grown 3.1% over the past four quarters. • During the period 1995-2003, US average labor productivity (ALP) increased at
between 22% and 48%. IT contributed 8.0% in 2003 and 12.0% in 2004 to the rise in GDP. Private fixed investment reached over $2 trillion in 1Q05—a 13.1% increase over 1Q04. ICT investment has been a driver of growth around the world, not just in the U.S.: •
between 22% and 48%. IT contributed 8.0% in 2003 and 12.0% in 2004 to
the rise in GDP. Private fixed investment reached over $2 trillion in
1Q05—a 13.1% increase over 1Q04.
ICT investment has been a driver of growth around the world, not just in
the U.S.:
•
In OECD countries, ICT investment typically accounted for between .3 and .8% growth in GDP during 1995-2001.
In OECD countries, ICT investment typically accounted for between .3 and .8%
growth in GDP during 1995-2001.
an average annual growth rate of 3.06% - more than double that of the previous 22 years (1973-1995). Nearly half (47%) of ALP growth was due to IT contributions to capital deepening and total factor productivity (TFP). (Source: Progress & Freedom Foundation, Digital Economy Fact Book, 7th edition, 2005)

page.title:
The President’s Broadband Vision
The President’s Broadband Vision
page.enlisting:
“This country needs a national goal for broadband technology . . . universal, affordable access for broadband technology by 2007.” – President George W. Bush,
“This country needs a national goal
for broadband technology . . .
universal, affordable access for
broadband technology by 2007.”
– President George W. Bush, – P r e s i d e n t
G e o r g e
W .
B u s h ,
Albuquerque, NM, March 26, 2004
Albuquerque, NM, March 26, 2004
page.normal_text:
"The role of government is not to create wealth; the role of our government is to create an environment in which the entrepreneur can flourish, in which minds can expand, in which technologies can reach new frontiers."
"The role of government is not to create wealth; the role of our
government is to create an environment in which the entrepreneur can
flourish, in which minds can expand, in which technologies can reach
new frontiers."

page.title:
U.S. Priorities
U.S. Priorities
page.enlisting:
◼ President Bush has a vision for making advanced technologies ◼ The telecom sector is growing dynamically, and many new technologies show great potential for expanding broadband deployment. IP services are having a very dramatic and positive impact on the U.S. economy. ◼ This Administration is committed to spectrum and broadband policies that create a domestic and international environment for economic growth by removing barriers to the implementation of U.S. technologies and services. ◼ The President’s goal will ensure that all Americans have the personal ◼ President Bush has a vision for making advanced technologies

page.title:
Technology’s Evolution
Technology’s Evolution T e c h n o l o g y ’ s
E v o l u t i o n
page.enlisting:
◼ 1969 → ARPANET ◼ 1971 → World’s first microprocessor developed ◼ 1973 → Cell phones invented, available to the public in 1977 ◼ 1984 → Internet named and switches to TCP/IP ◼ 1985 → 599 cell sites ◼ 1989 → WWW created ◼ 1992 → Digital cellular telephone system ◼ 1993 → 52MB additional RAM for PCs cost $1800 ◼ 1995 → 257 million personal computers (PC) in use worldwide; average ◼ 1999 → 375 million wireless subscribers worldwide (76 million U.S. subscribers) ◼ 2000 → More people watch cable television than broadcast channels ◼ 2002 → Wireless subscribers surpass fixed telephone line subscribers ◼ 2004 → Broadband subscribers surpass dial-up subscribers; more chips sold for ◼ TODAY → • Over 964 million Internet users worldwide • • • Smart phones bundled with Internet, email, text messaging, MP3 player, ring tones, digital camera, • PDAs incorporate Wi-Fi and Bluetooth technologies (i.e. Hewlett Packard IPAQ x2000) • • Average PC cost $841 (including peripherals) – dell.com desktops start at $379 • RAM costs less than one-hundredth what it did in 1993 1.4 billion wireless subscribers worldwide (194.5 million U.S. subscribers) 178,025 cell sites 820 million PCs in use worldwide – projected to surpass 1 billion by 2007 ◼ 1969 → ARPANET ◼ 1971 → World’s first microprocessor developed ◼ 1973 → Cell phones invented, available to the public in 1977 ◼ 1984 → Internet named and switches to TCP/IP ◼ 1985 → 599 cell sites ◼ 1989 → WWW created ◼ 1992 → Digital cellular telephone system ◼ 1993 → 52MB additional RAM for PCs cost $1800 ◼ 1995 → 257 million personal computers (PC) in use worldwide; average

page.title:
Shared Challenges Ahead
Shared Challenges Ahead
page.enlisting:
◼ We are making strides on both sides of the Atlantic. ◼ We need to continue to work together to promote free trade, private capital, entrepreneurship and support for private sector innovation. ◼ It is important to maintain a regulatory environment that allows the private sector do what it does best -- create jobs, drive capital investment, boost markets, and grow our economies. ◼ Secretary Gutierrez is committed to achieving the objectives of the EU-US TransAtlantic Agenda for Innovation Cooperation and recently participated in the November US-EU Ministerial in Brussels. ◼ We are making strides on both sides of the Atlantic.
◼ We are making strides on both sides of the Atlantic. ◼ W e
